lines.text: That woman? Do you know why I sat with her? Because she reminded me of you.
Really?

Of course, that's why I'm sitting here with you. Because you remind me of you. Your eyes, your throat, your lips! Everything about you reminds me of you. Except you. How do you account for that? If she figures that one out, she's good.
It's all right, that's in every contract. That's what they call a sanity clause.
[Fiorello laughs loudly]
You can't fool me! There ain't no Santay Claus!
I saw Mrs. Claypool first. Of course, her mother really saw her first but there's no point in bringing the Civil War into this.
You live here all alone?
Yes. Just me and my memories. I'm practically a hermit.
Oh. A hermit. I notice the table's set for four.
That's nothing - my alarm clock is set for eight. That doesn't prove a thing.
[Driftwood agrees to read the contract to Fiorello]
All right, I'll read it to you. Can you hear?
I haven't heard anything yet. Did you say anything?
Well, I haven't said anything worth hearing.
Well, that's-a why I didn't hear anything.
Well, that's why I didn't say anything.
And now, on with the opera. Let joy be unconfined. Let there be dancing in the streets, drinking in the saloons, and necking in the parlor.
You didn't happen to see my suit in there, did you?
Yeah, it was taking up too much room, so we sold it.
Did you get anything for it?
Uh... dollar forty.
That's my suit all right.
Two beers, bartender!
I'll take two beers, too.
[Driftwood opens a drawer in his trunk to find Tomasso sleeping]
That can't be my shirt, my shirt doesn't snore.
Shh! Don't wake him up. He's got insomnia, he's trying to sleep it off.
Ladies and gentlemen... I guess that takes in most of you...
Have you got any milk-fed chickens?
Yes, sir.
Well, squeeze the milk out of one and bring me a glass.
Do they allow tipping on the boat?
Yes, sir.
Have you got two fives?
Yes, sir!
Well, then you won't need the ten cents I was gonna give you.
You see that spaghetti? Now, behind that spaghetti is none other than Herman Gottlieb, director of the New York Opera Company. Do you follow me?
Yes.
Well stop following me or I'll have you arrested!
[Fiorello and Driftwood go over the first clause of their contract]

Now pay particular attention to this first clause because it's most important. It says the, uh..."The party of the first part shall be known in this contract as the party of the first part." How do you like that? That's pretty neat, eh?
No, that's no good.
What's the matter with it?
I dunno. Let's hear it again.
It says the, uh..."The party of the first part shall be known in this contract as the party of the first part."
That sounds a little better this time.
Well, it grows on you. Would you like to hear it once more?
Er... just the first part.
What do you mean? The... the party of the first part?
No, the first part of the party of the first part.

All right. It says the, uh, "The first part of the party of the first part shall be known in this contract as the first part of the party of the first part shall be known in this contract..." look, why should we quarrel about a thing like this? We'll take it right out, eh?
[the ship is sailing away from the dock]
Hey, have I got time to go back and pay my hotel bill?
Sorry, too late.
That suits me fine.

[to Tomasso, who's knocked out Lassparri]
Nice work, I think you got him. Ah, smelling salts? That will bring him to. You're sorry for what you did eh? That shows a nice spirit. Now he's coming along. He'll be fine.
And eight pieces of French pasty.
With two hard-boiled eggs.
And two hard-boiled eggs.
[Tomasso honks his horn]
Make that three hard-boiled eggs.

we forgot-a the airplane. So, we gotta sit down and we talk it over. Then I get-a the great idea. We no take-a gasoline, we no take-a the airplane. We take steamship, and that, friends, is how we fly across the ocean.
[Fiorello and Driftwood go over the second clause of their contract]
Now, it says, uh, "The party of the second part shall be known in this contract as the party of the second part."
Well, I don't know about that...
Now what's the matter?
I no like-a the second party, either.
Well, you should have come to the first party. We didn't get home 'til around four in the morning. I was blind for three days!
[in reference to Tomasso]
Wouldn't it be simpler if you just had him stuffed?
He's no olive.
Did you want a manicure?
No, come on in.
How do you do?

[resting his foot on Lassparri, who's been knocked out]
Hello.
What's the matter, mister?
Oh, we had an argument and he pulled a knife on me, so I shot him.

[raises a foot]
Do you mind if I...?
No no, go right ahead. Plenty of room.
I'm the engineer's assistant.
You know I had a premonition you were going to show up. The engineer's right there in the corner. You can chop your way right through.
You know the old saying. Two's company, five's a crowd.
Don't you know what duplicates are?
Sure, those five kids up in Canada.
You're willing to pay him a thousand dollars a night just for singing? Why, you can get a phonograph record of Minnie the Moocher for 75 cents. And for a buck and a quarter, you can get Minnie.
I've been sitting right here since seven o'clock.
Yes, with your back to me. When I invite a woman to dinner I expect her to look at my face. That's the price she has to pay.
What'll I say?
Tell them you're not here.
Suppose they don't believe me?
They'll believe you when you start talking.
Never in my life have I received such treatment. They threw an apple at me.
Well, watermelons are out of season.
Get off that bed. What would people say?
They'd probably say you're a very lucky woman.
If you had any real feeling for me you'd stop associating with the kind of riffraff I've seen you going around with.
You mean Gottlieb?
I mean those two uncouth men I saw you around the opera house with. I'm very grateful they're not on board the boat.

[gets up from his chair, concerned]
Why, have they slipped off?

[pulls him back into his chair]
Sit down!
What's a hermit doing with four beds?
Well, you see those first three beds?
Yes.
Last night, I counted five thousand sheep in those three beds, so I had to have another bed to sleep in. You wouldn't want me to sleep with the sheep, would you?
You got some mail for me?
Mail for you? You don't work here.
Well where am I gonna get my mail? I no work anyplace.

[to Mrs. Claypool]
All of New York will be under your feet!

[lifting the tablecloth]
Well, there's plenty of room.

[talking about "the greatest tenor in the world"]
Do you know America is waiting to hear him sing?
Well, he can sing loud, but he can't sing that loud.
Well, I think I can get America to meet him halfway.
What is that bed doing there?
I don't see it doing anything.
Now we're getting somewhere.
Are you sure you have everything, Otis?
Well, I haven't had any complaints yet.

[to carriage driver]
Hey you. I told you to slow that nag down. On account of you I almost heard the opera.
That's the fire escape. And, uh... that's a table, and this is a room, and there's the door leading out, and I wish you'd use it, I... I vant to be alone!
You'll be alone when I throw you in jail!
Isn't there a song like that, Henderson?
I am sure the familiar strains of Verdi's music will come back to you tonight, and Mrs. Claypool's cheques will probably come back to her in the morning.
[upon seeing a cast member made up to appear hideously ugly]
Boogie, boogie, boogie. How would you like to feel the way she looks?
[the waiter brings the bill]
Let me see that... 9 dollars and 40 cents? This is an outrage.
[to his dinner companion]
If I were you I wouldn't pay it.

[costumed as Pagliacci]
Now, what have you got to say to me?
Just this - can you sleep on your stomach with such big buttons on your pajamas?
Hey, who were you talking to?
I was talking to myself, and there's nothing you can do about it. I've had three of the best doctors in the East.
Was that a high C, or Vitamin D?
Say! Now, how did those two beds get together?
Well, you know how those things are, they breed like rabbits.

Signor Lassparri comes from a very famous family. His mother was a well-known bass singer. His father was the first man to stuff spaghetti with bicarbonate of soda, thus causing and curing indigestion at the same time.
The last time I was in this room there were four beds here.
Please! I'm not interested in your private life, Henderson.
What do you mean by humiliating me in front of all of those people? You're fired! Do you understand? You're fired!
Hey, you big bully. What's the idea of hitting that little bully?
Will you kindly let me handle my own affairs? Get out!
Say, I just remembered, I came back here looking for somebody. You don't know who it is, do you?
It's a funny thing, it just slipped my mind.
Could he sail tomorrow?
You pay him enough money, he could sail yesterday.
Let's go in my room and talk the situation over.
What situation?
Well, er... what situations have you got?
I most certainly will not go to your room.
OK, then I'll stay here.
All right, all right, all right! I'll come, but get out.
Shall we say, uh, ten minutes?
Yes, ten minutes, anything. But go!
Because if you're not there in ten minutes, I'll be back here in eleven. With squeaky shoes on!

[attempting to sell insurance to a ship porter]
I have here an accident policy that will absolutely protect you no matter what happens. If you lose a leg, we'll help you look for it.
I cannot let the evening pass without paying a little tribute to our distinguished guests of honor - the three greatest aviators in the world.
Three greatest aviators, but you notice they're traveling by boat.
And what was it you wanted to see me about?
I suppose I sent for you?
Well you meant to. Didn't she, Marie?
But I will still remember the happiness we've known.
Ladies and gentleman. It's a great pleasure that I welcome you all to the final night of the voyage.
Ricardo, how do you feel?
After a meal like that great. I could sing my head off. Cosi-Cosa. It's a wonderful word tra-la-la-la.

[beginning a speech disguised as one of the aviators]
Friends.
Go fast. I can see a man with a rope out there.
How we happen to come to America is a great story, but I no tell that.
Am I crazy or are there only two beds in here?
Now which question do you want me to answer first, Henderson?
Hello toots.
Well. What are you doing here? This is Mr. Gottlieb's box.
He couldn't come, so he gave me his ticket. He couldn't get dressed, so he gave me his clothes.

[at the opera]
Well, who's ahead?
It's none of my business, but I think there's a brace of woodpeckers in the orchestra.
Did you want your nails long or short?
Better make them short. It's getting pretty crowded in here.

[in an overcrowded stateroom]
It is my imagination, or is it getting crowded in here?
Wait a minute. Before he sings, you gotta sign a contract. And I get 10 percent.
And I get 10 percent too.
